NAIROBI, Oct 20 (IPS) - The tips of our fingers have densely packed nerve endings. That is why a miniscule paper cut activates our pain receptors and causes stubborn pain for a day or two. Now consider that a clitoris has over 10,000 nerve endings. It is the human femaleâs most sensitive erogenous zone, explaining the sexual pleasure it elicits at the slightest touch. A paper cut on your clitoris would be agonizing yet does not compare to the pain of female genital mutilation â or FGM.

Read the full story, âTo Attain the SDGs, We Must End Female Genital Mutilationâ, on globalissues.org â

This week, the World Bank governing body approved a new vision statement that clarifies that the Bank can tackle climate change as part of its mission to alleviate global poverty on âa livable planet.â Also this week, the new World Bank President Ajay Banga suggested that heâll be consider redirecting subsidies away from fossil fuels and towards climate action.

articles.description: Hurricane Norma is strengthening as it moves towards the southern tip of Mexico's Baja California peninsula. The storm is expected to bring heavy rainfall and strong winds to popular tourist resorts in the area. The governor has urged people to stay indoors and businesses to close. Shelters have been set up to accommodate up to 10,000 people. The National Hurricane Center warns of dangerous conditions and possible flooding. Norma is located some 195 miles (314 km) south of Cabo San Lucas.
articles.title: 'Erratic' Hurricane Norma on track to hit Mexico's Baja California

articles.description: President Joe Biden has stated that Hamas' recent attack on Israel was aimed at disrupting the potential normalization of ties between Israel and Saudi Arabia. Saudi Arabia, which has not followed its Gulf neighbors in establishing relations with Israel, has stated that Palestinian statehood goals should be addressed first. Biden had plans to sit down with the Saudis, making the potential normalization of relations a top priority for Secretary of State Antony Blinken during his trip to Riyadh.
articles.title: Biden says Hamas attack aimed to disrupt Saudi-Israel normalization ties

articles.description: President Joe Biden assured European Union leaders during their meeting at the White House that the United States will provide substantial aid to Ukraine and Israel. Biden emphasized the unity between the US and EU in supporting Ukraine and tackling economic challenges, while also discussing the need to back Israel after the recent Hamas attack and establish trade standards with China.
articles.title: US commitment to Ukraine a central question as Biden meets with EU heads during congressional chaos

articles.description: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has dismissed claims by Russian President Vladimir Putin of "ethnic discrimination" against athletes excluded from international sport. The IOC has advised sports bodies to vet Russian athletes for competing as neutral individuals without national identity for the 2024 Paris Olympics. The IOC stated that these measures are a reaction to the breach of the Olympic Charter by the Russian and Belarusian governments.
articles.title: IOC hits back at Putin claim of 'ethnic discrimination' against Russia's potential Olympic athletes

articles.description: The armed wing of Hamas, the Izz el-Deen al-Qassam Brigades, has released two US hostages from Gaza for humanitarian reasons, according to their spokesman. The release came as a response to Qatari mediation efforts in the war with Israel. The Israeli and American officials have not confirmed or denied the claim. Hamas had previously stated that they took around 200 hostages during their rampage on Israeli towns, and they have released some of them. The Israeli military has stated that most of the hostages are still alive, including over 20 children.
articles.title: 2 American hostages freed: Hamas

articles.description: Britain's Labour Party dealt a crushing blow to PM Rishi Sunak's Conservatives on Friday, winning two previously safe parliamentary seats in victories leader Keir Starmer said showed voters wanted change at the next national election. The double defeat showed a big slump in support for the governing Conservatives, who have won the last four national votes, and suggests Labour is on course to win power for the first time since 2010 at an election expected next year. While so-called by-elections are often lost by the governing party, the scale of the defeat in two parliamentary seats the Conservatives have held for years piles pressure on Sunak.
articles.title: United Kingdom's Labour deals big by-poll blows to Sunak

articles.description: A US navy warship intercepted three cruise missiles and several drones launched from Yemen towards Israel. The missiles and drones were launched by pro-Iranian Houthi rebels, highlighting the risk of the conflict between Israel and Hamas escalating into a wider war. The Biden administration has deployed additional troops and aircraft carriers to deter Iran and its proxies from engaging in a regional war. The US military is assessing the responsible party for the drone attacks. The Pentagon spokesman emphasized the importance of containing the conflict and stated that any American response would be determined by the US.
articles.title: United States shoots down drones & missiles from Yemen

articles.description: Former US President Donald Trump has been fined $5,000 by a New York judge for violating a partial gag order. The judge also warned Trump of possible jail time for future violations. The gag order was imposed after Trump insulted the judge's law clerk on social media. Trump and his two sons are facing charges of inflating the value of Trump Organization assets.
articles.title: Trump fined $5,000 by New York judge for violating gag order

articles.description: Violence in the West Bank has escalated amid ongoing clashes between Israeli soldiers and settlers and Palestinians. Concerns are rising that the territory could become a third front in a wider conflict, following Israel's bombardment of Gaza and clashes with Hezbollah at the Lebanon border. Over 80 Palestinians have been killed and more than 900 people have been arrested since October 7. The violence poses a challenge to both Israel and the Palestinian Authority, with growing support for armed resistance. The Israeli military is on high alert, anticipating attacks from Hamas militants in the West Bank.
articles.title: West Bank a possible 'third front' for Israel

articles.description: Israel launched airstrikes on the Gaza Strip, targeting areas where Palestinians had sought safety, and started evacuating an Israeli town near Lebanon's border, indicating a possible ground invasion. Israel's defense minister stated that they do not plan to control civilians in Gaza after their war with Hamas and expect a three-phase war. The Israeli military struck more than 100 targets tied to Hamas. Palestinian militants have launched over 6,900 rockets into Israel, causing tensions in the West Bank. Over one million people have been displaced in Gaza, with overwhelmed hospitals rationing medical supplies and fuel. Aid delivery from Egypt remains uncertain.
articles.title: Israel prepares for a 3-phase war against Hamas

articles.description: Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni has announced her separation from her partner, TV journalist Andrea Giambruno, who has faced backlash for making sexist comments. Meloni stated that she should not be judged for his remarks and will no longer address questions about his behavior. The split comes as Meloni marks her first year in office, leading a right-wing coalition government that prioritizes traditional family values. The couple, who have a 7-year-old daughter, had been together for nearly 10 years. Giambruno's controversial comments and actions have been a subject of public scrutiny.
articles.title: Italy PM Giorgia Meloni announces separation from partner after his sexist TV comments

articles.description: Two American hostages, Judith Tai Raanan and her daughter Natalie Shoshana Raanan, who were abducted by Hamas during their stay at Kibbutz Nahal Oz., have been freed and identified as Chicago-area residents are en-route to a military base in central Israel. They were handed over to Israeli forces at the border of the Gaza Strip and are being reunited with their family. The release of the  two hostages was made possible through a partnership between Qatar and Israel.
articles.title: Hamas releases American mother and daughter held hostage after Qatari mediation

articles.description: Judge Arthur Engoron, who is presiding over Donald Trump's civil fraud trial, threatened to hold the former president in contempt for violating a court order. Trump's disparaging social media post about a court staffer remained on his campaign website for weeks after the judge ordered it to be deleted. Engoron warned of possible fines or even jail time for Trump. The judge had issued a limited gag order, prohibiting personal attacks on court staff involved in the case.
articles.title: Judge threatens to hold Donald Trump in contempt after deleted post is found on campaign website

articles.description: Turkish Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan expressed concerns about US President Joe Biden's visit to Israel, suggesting it appeared to endorse the destruction in Gaza, highlighting that this would be remembered in history. Speaking to state broadcaster TRT Haber, Fidan said Israel had "changed the narrative" about its involvement in a blast at a Gaza hospital on Tuesday, and added he hoped a summit in Cairo on Saturday would yield an agreement to stop Israel's offensive.
articles.title: Turkey says Biden's Israel visit amounted to approval of destruction in Gaza

articles.description: Representative Jim Jordan of Ohio has lost an internal vote to continue as the nominee for speaker within his party, creating further uncertainty in the House. This comes after his third unsuccessful attempt to secure the position. With no consensus on a path forward, the House is paralyzed despite growing pressure to address urgent matters. Jordan's loss reveals that he had actually lost ground, with 25 Republicans opposing him compared to 22 in his previous attempt. The Republican party now needs to find a new candidate for speaker.
articles.title: Republicans drop Jim Jordan as Speaker nominee after failed 3rd vote

articles.description: US President Joe Biden said he believes that the first aid trucks to reach Gaza via the Rafah crossing from Egypt within the next 24 to 48 hours, with a commitment from Israel and Egypt to facilitate the aid despite the need for road repairs. "I believe in the next 24 to 48 hours the first 20 trucks will come across the border," Biden said as he met European Union chiefs at the White House.
articles.title: Biden says Gaza aid likely to cross in 'next 24 to 48 hours'

articles.description: Kenneth Chesebro, a lawyer for Donald Trump's 2020 election campaign, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit filing of false documents in the Georgia election case just before his trial. This follows Sidney Powell's guilty plea. These developments prevent the first trial and are part of four state or federal cases against Trump for his efforts to reverse the election results. Meanwhile, Trump maintains his innocence and asserts his loss was due to fraud.
articles.title: Another Trump lawyer reaches plea deal with Georgia prosecutors

articles.description: Egypt is hosting a summit on the Gaza crisis, but the absence of key leaders, including the US, has lowered expectations for its outcome. The summit aims to bring together Arab and European heads of state to discuss the ongoing conflict in Gaza and the future of the Palestinian issue. However, there is uncertainty about who will attend, with no confirmation from the US, China, or Russia. Arab countries have expressed anger at Israel's actions in Gaza.
articles.title: Egypt peace summit may struggle to foster unity on Gaza conflict

articles.description: Over 4,200 people have been displaced from villages in south Lebanon due to clashes on the border with Israel. Local officials are concerned about the lack of resources and preparation for a larger exodus if the conflict escalates. Many of the displaced individuals are staying in schools in the city of Tyre, but resources are limited. The Lebanese government has appealed to international organizations for assistance. The ongoing clashes have killed at least 22 people in Lebanon.
articles.title: In Lebanon, thousands are displaced from border towns by clashes, stretching state resources

articles.description: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) proposed strict austerity measures for Pakistan's development budget, expressing concerns over the allocation of funds for new projects. The IMF suggests that funds should be allocated to ongoing projects that are near completion instead of starting new ones. IMF also suggested for recovery of Rs 46 billion loss of gas companies from July to September. During the talks, the IMF officials were informed that caretaker Finance Minister Dr Shamshad Akhtar is in China, as per ARY News
articles.title: IMF proposes Pakistan to adopt austerity in new development projects

articles.description:
A wounded Palestinian child, crying and clutching onto adults carrying him into a hospital. A deceased Israeli soldier's loved ones, their faces wracked with grief as they mourn. Dozens of small posters, each one picturing a missing Israeli, as another sign blares just one word, scribbled in bright red: âPain.â

The images tell a story of unspeakable tragedy and palpable fear, as the war between Israel and Hamas prepares to enter its third week. The deadliest of the five Gaza wars, it has left more than 1,400 people in Israel dead, as well as more than 4,100 Palestinians, according to the Hamas-run Gaza Health Ministry. 

The destruction is clear throughout Gaza, as Palestinians desperately search for survivors and are forced to walk through rubble left behind after Israeli bombardments. And anguish continues to ripple throughout Israel, as mothers bury their children, flags and flowers line even more graves, and couples become separated as one partner heads into combat. 

Others,...
articles.title: AP PHOTOS: Grief, devastation overwhelm region in second week of Israel-Hamas war

articles.description:
Satellite photos analyzed Friday by The Associated Press show a long convoy of trucks filled with humanitarian aid waiting to cross the border from Egypt to the Gaza Strip. 

More than 200 trucks carrying roughly 3,000 tons of aid were positioned near the crossing, according to aid officials. The provisions are intended to bring some relief to the Palestinians in Gaza, which is being blockaded by Israel in response to the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas militants on towns in southern Israel. 

Many in Gaza, reduced to eating one meal a day and without enough water to drink, are waiting desperately for the aid. It was unclear whether fuel would be allowed across to power hospital generators. 

On Friday, workers began repairing damaged to the crossing caused by Israeli bombings. Officials hoped to open the crossing on Saturday.
articles.title: Trucks mass at Gaza border as they wait to bring aid to desperate Palestinians

articles.description:
Oct. 13-19, 2023

Rallies supporting the Palestinians were held in Indonesia, Philippines and Australia. Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin with other foreign leaders attend the Belt and Road Forum in Beijing, and people row a long boat in a procession carrying Buddha images to a monastery during the pagoda festival in Myanmar. 

This photo gallery highlights some of the most compelling images in Asia made or published by The Associated Press in the past week.

The selection was curated by AP photo editor Masayo Yoshida in Tokyo.

Follow AP visual journalism:

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/apnews

AP Images on Twitter: http://twitter.com/AP_Images

AP Images blog: http://apimagesblog.com

articles.description:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
    

  
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated.
 Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. 
The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish governmentâs earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response â waiting for aid and rescue teams â but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the disâ¦
articles.title: Who is responsible for Turkeyâs bad buildings?

articles.description:
Getty Images
    

  
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy â and how we can do the same with some of our own.
 Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons.
That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russiaâs nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. âNearly every commerciaâ¦
articles.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.

articles.description:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
    

  
What Turkey and Syriaâs deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth.
 In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. âIt was like the apocalypse,â Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters.  
The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last weekâs earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an uâ¦
articles.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live

articles.description:
A suspected Chinese spy balloon flies above Charlotte, North Carolina, on February 4, 2023.Â  | Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
    

  
As all these objects fall, a new space race is rising.
 Now that the US military has shot down a suspected spy balloon from China and three other unidentified flying objects, there will be debates about the UFOsâ meaning, their capabilities, and why they were all up there in the first place. 
Though former CIA Director Michael Hayden said the initial balloonâs threat to the welfare of Americans was vastly inflated, others described the incident as a wake-up call. Former Trump national security adviser H.R. McMaster hopes it will lead to a âSputnik moment,â harkening back to the US space race with the Soviet Union. The Wall Street Journal even warâ¦
articles.title: Why the balloon and UFO affairs are a Sputnik moment

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
French Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne avoided parliamentary censure in an early morning vote on Saturday after she forced the government's budget plan through the National Assembly without a vote. 
The motion to censure Borne â the 18th levelled at her since she assumed the office â was brought by the left-wing Nupes alliance after the prime minister activated Article 49.3 to adopt the public finance bill without a vote.
The motion received just 193 of the 289 votes needed to succeed, an unsurprising outcome in light of the lack of support from the centre-right.
Its rejection constitutes the adoption of the 2023-2027 budget program, which now moves to the Senate, the upper house of the French parliament.
The speaker for Nupes, socialist Philippe Brun, accused the government of "favouring with the greatest servility a very well-endowed minority of the French" despite "an immense inflationary crisis".
President Emmanuel Macron had "tried to make parliament disappear with his repeated (use of) 49.3", Brun added.
The far right had supported the left's motion of censure, accusing Borne of the "repeated and abusive use of 49.3".
Borne, for her part, hit back at both factions, saying "demagoguery is your only budgetary course".
The government also resorted to Article 49.3 earlier this year to push through unpopular pension reforms, sparking violent protests.
(AFP)
articles.title: French PM Borne survives censure vote after pushing through budget plan

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Billionaire Elon Musk on Saturday waded into German politics at a time of a heated debate on immigration across Europe, saying Berlin-funded migrant rescue operations in the Mediterranean could be seen as an "invasion" of Italy.
Musk, who was born in South Africa, has Canadian nationality and lives in the United States, shared a post calling for a victory of the far-right party AfD a week before regional elections in two major German states.
Berlin is locked a row with Italy over the NGO sea operations, with Italian Prime Minister Giorgio Meloni on Friday demanding that charity ships disembark the rescued migrants in their own countries.
Musk shared a post on X by a user identified as "Radio Genoa" that blasted German NGO operations in the Mediterranean and expressed hope that "AfD wins thâ¦
articles.title: Elon Musk slams German-funded migrants rescue Med operations

articles.description: By Philip Pullella VATICAN CITY (Reuters) - Pope Francis on Saturday further cemented his legacy, elevating 21 prelates to the high rank of cardinal and significantly raising the percentage of electors chosen by him who will have the right to vote for his successor. At a ceremony in St. Peter's Square known as a consistory, Francis "created" 21 new cardinals, the red-hatted "princes of the Church" who are his closest advisers at the Vatican and around the world. There are now 137 cardinal electors, about 73 percent of them chosen by Francis. This increases - but does not guarantee - the possib...
articles.title: Pope Francis cements legacy, stamps Church future with new cardinals

articles.description: Mexico City (AFP) - United Nations experts on Friday called on Mexico to crack down on extortion by police and other officials targeting vulnerable migrants in flagrant violation of their human rights. The UN Working Group on Arbitrary Detention also urged the Mexican government to avoid a repeat of the tragedy last year when 40 migrants died in a fire while behind bars. More than 240,000 undocumented migrants and asylum seekers were detained in Mexico in the first half of 2023, including many children, the experts said at the conclusion of a 12-day visit. According to the Mexican constitution...
articles.title: UN experts urge Mexico to stamp out extortion of migrants

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
The head of Italy's rhythmic gymnastics national team, suspended after a group of former athletes made allegations of bullying over their weight and diets, received a simple warning on Friday.
Emanuela Maccarani had been relieved of her role within the Italian gymnastics federation (FGI) pending investigations into her behaviour.
On Friday, the FGI disciplinary commission, followed recommendations of the body's federal prosecutor Michele Rossetti that "there was no evidence of intentionally or excessively vexatious behavior in relations with the gymnasts".
"There was no relentless effort to obtain an additional medal," he added.
Maccarani's assistant Olga Tishina was cleared of any fault.
In late October, three former rhythmic gymnastics, including two double world champions, made claims of abuse in a series of interviews with daily La Repubblica.
One of the gymnasts, Anna Basta, said she had twice thought about killing herself, while 19-year-old Nina Corradini quit the national set-up in 2021 after spending "every minute of the previous few months wishing I could escape".
Giulia Galtarossa, a world champion in 2009 and 2010 who is and now 31, said she was berated by a coaching assistant for eating a pear, and handed her diet sheet with the message "we have a little piggy in the squad".
Maccarani had held the position of Italy's rhythmic gymnastics team's technical director since 2018. She was also the team's long-time head coach.
She had denied claims of psychological abuse, saying the accusations came from disgruntled gymnasts who were not selected for Olympic squads.
Parents of gymnasts training at the national centre in Desio wrote a letter to the head of Italy's Olympic Committee in support of the 57-year-old, who has won a raft of medals for Italy since taking charge in 1996.
Â© 2023 AFP
articles.title: 'We have a little piggy in the squad:' Italy's gymnastics chief gets off with warning after bullying claims

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Sprinter Kimia Yousofi said she was "here to represent Afghan girls" as she competed at the Asian Games on Friday in defiance of the Taliban.
Yousofi, who resettled in Australia last year after fleeing persecution in her homeland, is one of 14 women athletes listed in Afghanistan's team in Hangzhou.
"The most important thing for me is to represent our girls in Afghanistan," she said.
The other Afghan women are competing in volleyball and cycling, and like Yousofi have built new lives for themselves around the world.
Women's sport in Afghanistan was effectively banned by the Taliban when they returned to power in 2021.
That meant no women traveling from Afghanistan in the delegation of more than 120 competitors, coaches and supervisors.
But with the help of overseas sports bodies, foreign-bâ¦
articles.title: Afghan woman sprinter sends message of defiance at Asian Games

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Spainâs conservative leader saw his final bid to become prime minister rejected by parliament on Friday, paving the way for Socialist incumbent Pedro Sanchez to have another shot at cobbling together a majority â with the backing of separatist parties whose support could cost him dearly.
Two months after an inconclusive general election resulted in a hung parliament, Spainâs protracted political horse-trading has delivered a first, highly expected verdict: there will be no conservative government led by Alberto Nunez-Feijoo â at least not in this legislature.
On Friday, the leader of the right-wing Popular Party (PP) conceded defeat in his second attempt to win the backing of Spainâs Congress of Deputies, the lower house of parliament, falling short of the 176 seats required for a majorityâ¦
articles.title: A compromise too far? Spainâs Sanchez has âlittle wiggle roomâ to stay in power

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Relatives of Saudis facing heavy sentences for social media posts are calling on the kingdom's de facto ruler to take action after he voiced shame over their cases.
In a rare interview with Fox News last week, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman was asked about Mohammed al-Ghamdi, a retired school teacher sentenced to death in July for posts on X, formerly Twitter, where he had around 10 followers.
Prince Mohammed acknowledged that details of the case described in media reports were "true" and said he disapproved of the judgement.
"We are not happy with that. We are ashamed of that," he said, blaming "bad laws" he had so far been unable to change.
He also raised the possibility that Ghamdi might be spared death.
"I'm hoping that in the next phase of trials, the judge there is more experiencedâ¦
articles.title: Relatives of detained Saudis urge 'ashamed' prince to act on cases

articles.author: David McAfee
articles.description:
Donald Trump Thursday night took a swipe at Fox News and the GOP debates, calling on an end to the primary and on those in the media to "stop with the bad debates and negative ads."
Trump on Thursday suggested that some of the GOP candidates did better than others at the recent Republican debate, even giving a report card for his rivals.

After that, he called for an end to the debates altogether.
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?
Trump, who has skipped the first two debates and said he plans to avoid them all, had this to say late Thursday.

"The second Republican Primary Debate on FoxNews had the Lowest Viewership since 2016. Their overall Ratings are down 30%," he added. "FOX NEEDS MAGA, THEY JUST DONâT KNOW IT YET. STOP WITH THE BAD DEBATES & NEGATIVE ADS, NO MORE. GET YOUR ACT TOGETHER BEFORE IT IS TOO LATE! DJT."
articles.title: Trump begs Fox News to 'stop with the bad debates and negative ads'

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Six female migrants trapped inside a refrigerated food truck were rescued by French police after one of the women made a distress call to a reporter, the BBC and French authorities said Thursday.
The women â four Vietnamese and two Iraqis â hid for hours in a truck loaded with boxes of bananas in northern France, believing the vehicle was on its way to the U.K. or Ireland.
When they realized that the truck was going the opposite way, they started to panic in the cold and cramped, dark space. One of them managed to reach a BBC reporter in London, who then helped the women alert French police Wednesday.
French prosecutor Laetitia Francart said the truck driver, who was in fact heading for Italy, was not at fault. The women told investigators that the driver wasnât involved, âsaying that theyâ¦
articles.title: Six female migrants rescued from truck in France after calling journalist for help

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Twin shootings in Rotterdam on Thursday have resulted in an unknown number of fatalities, police said.
A gunman dressed in combat gear opened fire in a flat in the Dutch city then burst into a nearby medical centre. Fires broke out in both places but were later extinguished.
âThe two shooting incidents in Rotterdam have resulted in fatalities. We will first inform family and relatives and will explain more later,â the city police said in a statement on X, formerly Twitter.
Elite police units had burst into the hospital in the Dutch city searching for the suspect, who was armed with a handgun, authorities said.
The suspect is 32 and the motive for the attack is unknown, local news agency ANP said, citing police. He is suspected of carrying out both shootings and there is not a second shooter, police said.
Pictures from the scene showed people streaming out of the hospital, including medics and patients, as police in body armour moved in. Police helicopters buzzed overhead.
Medics in white coats wheeled patients out on stretchers and wheelchairs
Police had earlier said the suspect was wearing âcombat-styleâ clothes, was tall, with black hair and carrying a backpack.
âFirst there was a shooting on the fourth floor. Four or five shots were fired. Then a Molotov cocktail was thrown into the education centre,â said a medical student cited by RTL Nieuws, who did not give his name.
âThere was a lot of panic and screaming... I didnât hear any shots, just the panic and thatâs what I started to act on,â public broadcaster NOS cited another eyewitness as saying.
Rotterdam is often the scene of shootings, usually attributed to score settling by rival drug gangs.
Authorities were expected to hold a news conference shortly to give more details.
In 2019, three people were shot dead on a tram in Utrecht, sparking a huge manhunt.
And in 2011, the country was left shocked when 24-year Tristan van der Vlis killed six people and wounded 10 others in a rampage at a packed shopping mall.
(AFP)
articles.title: Gunman kills several in Rotterdam shooting spree, Dutch police say

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Veteran actor Michael Gambon, who was known to many for his portrayal of Hogwarts headmaster Albus Dumbledore in six of the eight âHarry Potterâ films, has died, his publicist said Thursday. He was 82.
A statement by his family, issued by his publicist, said he died following âa bout of pneumonia.â
âWe are devastated to announce the loss of Sir Michael Gambon. Beloved husband and father, Michael died peacefully in hospital with his wife Anne and son Fergus at his bedside,â his family said.
No matter what role he took on in a career that lasted more than five decades, Gambon was always instantly recognizable by the deep and drawling tones of his voice. He was cast as the much-loved Dumbledore after the death of his predecessor, Richard Harris, in 2002.
He once acknowledged not having read aâ¦
articles.title: Michael Gambon, who played Dumbledore in âHarry Potterâ films, dies at 82

articles.description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken met Thursday with India's foreign minister amid a simmering row between New Delhi and Ottawa over allegations of Indian government involvement in the killing of a Sikh activist in Canada.
articles.title: Blinken meets Indian foreign minister as row between India and Canada simmers

articles.author: Bill Gertz
articles.description: False electronic signals imitating satellite data from Global Position System satellites recently caused complete navigation failures for 12 aircraft flights near Iran, according to a private aircraft security group.
articles.title: Electronic GPS 'spoofing' behind civilian jet navigation failures over Iraq

articles.author: Jim Heintz
articles.description: The exodus of ethnic Armenians this week from the region known as Nagorno-Karabakh has been a vivid and shocking tableau of fear and misery. Roads are jammed with cars lumbering with heavy loads, waiting for hours in traffic jams. People sit amid mounds of hastily packed luggage.
articles.title: Why this week's exodus from embattled Nagorno-Karabakh reflects decades of animosity

articles.author: Rob Gillies
articles.description: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau apologized Wednesday for Parliament's recognition of a man who fought alongside the Nazis during last week's address by Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.
articles.title: Trudeau apologizes for recognition of Nazi unit war veteran in Canadian Parliament

articles.author: Ben Wolfgang
articles.description: The toxic cocktail of terrorism and political instability sweeping across Africa is reaching a new peak. And hope that the tide can be turned is hitting a new low.
articles.title: 'Almost insurmountable' task: Africa emerges as unstable hot spot for terror, coups

articles.author: Lorne Cook
articles.description: Three years after unveiling a plan for sweeping reform of the European Union's outdated asylum rules, government ministers struggled on Thursday to overcome yet another obstacle to putting the new system in place, fueling doubt as to whether it will ever see the light of day.
articles.title: E.U. struggles to update asylum laws three years on from a sweeping reform. And the clock is ticking

articles.author: Illia Novikov
articles.description: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has appointed former Ukrainian soccer great Andriy Shevchenko as a special adviser and British actor Mark Strong as an ambassador to the charity that the Ukrainian president set up to raise money for Ukraine, his office announced.
articles.title: Ukraine's Zelenskyy taps celebrities for roles as special adviser and charity ambassador

articles.author: Mallory Wilson
articles.description: Sen. John Fetterman and Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis have found common ground -- and they don't want the Chinese government on it.
articles.title: Fetterman aligns with DeSantis on China, says Beijing should own 'zero' farmland in U.S.

articles.description: A 16-year-old boy was arrested Thursday in northern England in connection with what authorities described as the "deliberate" felling of a famous tree that had stood for nearly 200 years next to the Roman landmark Hadrian's Wall.
articles.title: 16-year-old arrested over 'deliberate' felling of a famous Sycamore Gap tree at Hadrian's Wall

articles.author: Hanna Arhirova
articles.description: NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg met with President Volodymyr Zelenskyy to discuss the status of the war and needs of troops on Thursday, the day after Russia accused Ukraine's Western allies of helping plan and conduct last week's missile strike on the Black Sea Fleet's headquarters on the annexed Crimean Peninsula.
articles.title: NATO's secretary-general meets with Zelenskyy to discuss battlefield and ammunition needs in Ukraine

articles.author: Jintamas Saksornchai
articles.description: Police in Thailand said Thursday they made one of the country's biggest ever seizures of illicit drugs, a haul including methamphetamine, crystal meth and heroin, with a total estimated street value of about 300 million baht ($8.2 million).
articles.title: Thai police say drug bust nets methamphetamine, crystal meth and heroin worth $8.2 million

articles.author: Qassim Abdul-Zahra, Kareem Chehayeb
articles.description: Iraq's prime minister on Thursday visited injured patients and the families of victims in northern Iraq days after a deadly wedding fire killed around 100 people, as two more people died from their injuries.
articles.title: Iraq's prime minister visits wedding fire victims as 2 more people die from their injuries

articles.author: Matthew Lee, Kim Tong-hyung, Lolita C. Baldor
articles.description: The American soldier who sprinted into North Korea across the heavily fortified border between the Koreas more than two months ago was whisked to a Texas Army base Thursday for medical checks and interviews after his return to the U.S., according to the Pentagon.
articles.title: American soldier who bolted into North Korea 2 months ago has returned to the U.S.

articles.author: Issam Adwan
articles.description: Israel reopened a main crossing with the Gaza Strip on Thursday, easing tensions and allowing thousands of Palestinian laborers to enter the country for the first time since it was sealed earlier this month.
articles.title: Israel reopens the main Gaza crossing for Palestinian laborers and tensions ease

articles.author: Tia Goldenberg, Moshe Edri
articles.description: Israel's Supreme Court on Thursday was hearing a challenge to a law that makes it harder to remove a sitting prime minister, which critics say is designed to protect Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu who has been working to reshape the justice system while he is on trial for alleged corruption.
articles.title: Israel's High Court hears a challenge to a law that makes it harder to remove Netanyahu from office

articles.author: Mike Glenn
articles.description: Thousands of the U.S. military's most junior enlisted personnel are facing serious health and safety risks not on some foreign battlefield, but in the very barracks where they live.
articles.title: Lawmakers demand accountability after report on squalid military barracks

articles.author: Bill Gertz
articles.description: China's emergence as a major nuclear power has set off a debate among U.S. strategic analysts over how best to deter war in the new three-way nuclear standoff between Washington, Beijing and Moscow.
articles.title: Nuclear targeting debate: Cities or militaries?

articles.description: The Czech Republic's government on Wednesday approved a Defense Ministry plan to acquire two dozen U.S. F-35 fighter jets in a deal worth around 150 billion Czech koruna ($6.5 billion).
articles.title: Czech government approved defense ministry plan to acquire two dozen U.S. F-35 fighter jets

articles.author: Mark A. Kellner
articles.description: An ancient inscription paraphrasing the first two verses of Psalm 86 has been uncovered at a remote site in Israel's Judean desert, archaeologists from the Hebrew University of Jerusalem said Wednesday.
articles.title: Ancient inscription of Bible verse found at Judean archaeological site

articles.description: Polish and U.S. officials signed an agreement Wednesday in Warsaw for the construction of Poland's first nuclear power plant, part of an effort by the Central European nation to move away from polluting fossil fuels.
articles.title: Plans for Poland's first nuclear power plant move ahead as U.S., Polish officials sign an agreement

articles.description: The Biden administration is admitting Israel into a select group of countries whose citizens are allowed to travel to the United States without getting a visa in advance.

articles.description: Travis King, the troubled U.S. Army private who shocked the world when he defected to North Korea in July, is back in U.S. hands after Pyongyang abruptly deported him.

articles.description: Iran claimed on Wednesday that it successfully launched an imaging satellite into space, a move that could further ratchet up tensions with Western nations that fear its space technology could be used to develop nuclear weapons.
articles.title: Iran says it has successfully launched an imaging satellite into orbit amid tensions with the West

articles.description: Azerbaijan's border guard service said Wednesday it has detained the former head of Nagorno-Karabakh's separatist government as he tried to cross into Armenia.

articles.description: A Mexican mother bravely shielded her son after a bear leapt on a picnic table and devoured the tacos and enchiladas meant for the boy's birthday dinner, inches from his face.

articles.description: A fire at a wedding hall in northern Iraq killed at least 100 people and injured 150 others, authorities said Wednesday.

articles.author: Mike Glenn

articles.description:
Relief Web: Israel destroys a quarter of northern Gaza Strip, Palestinian death toll exceeds 4,000Â 
Geneva â Israel is conducting the largest campaign of destruction of buildings and residential houses in the Gaza Strip in modern history, Euro-Med Human Rights Monitor stated, as part of a wide-scale military attack ongoing since the seventh of this month.Â 
Euro-Med Monitor emphasised that Israel is focusing its attacks on the Gaza and North Gaza governorates through a systematic destruction campaign, aiming to force displacement and population transfer against the residents of these governorates.Â 
The Israeli army has warned the residents of both governorates, which are home to nearly a million people, to evacuate the areas and move to the central and southern sections of the Strip, a measure that raises serious legal and humanitarian concerns as it endangers the safety of civilians.

Â 
Read more ....

Â 
Update #1: Gaza war death toll rises to 4,137 (Economic Times)
Â 
Update #2: UN says 4,200 people killed in Israel, Gaza conflict in 10 days (Anadolu Agency)

Â 
WNU Editor: The numbers are horrifying. As of yesterday (link here), just in Gaza alone 3,785 Palestinians have been killed in Israeli strikes since Oct.7. Of this 3,785 total, 1,524 were children and 1,000 were women. 

Â 
Update #3: These shortages have the potential to be just as destructive as bombs if not alleviated soon .... Gaza conditions worsen amid warnings that shortages could âkill many, many peopleâ (CNN).
articles.title: Euro-Med Human Rights Monitor Says A Quarter Of Northern Gaza Has Been Destroyed. UN Says 4,200 People Killed After 10 Days

Satellite imagery shows where Israel has deployed hundreds of tanks and armored vehicles to two fields north of Gaza, in preparation for a potential ground invasion. The New York Times is mapping developments. https://t.co/yO3VBV6HCV pic.twitter.com/crAzlVakZj
â The New York Times (@nytimes) October 19, 2023
  
Daily Mail: Ready for war: Satellite images show hundreds of Israeli tanks gathered in fields four miles north of Gaza as IDF prepares to send tens of thousands of soldiers in to war-torn strip to destroy HamasÂ 
* Satellite images have shown how Israeli forces are gearing up on the northern border of Gaza, as they prepare for ground invasionÂ 
* Pictures have shown hundreds of armored vehicles including tanks, personnel carriers and bulldozersÂ 
* The Israeli Defense Minister Yoav Gallant has told soldiers at the border to 'get organized, be ready' for their move into Palestinian territoryÂ 
Satellite imagery has revealed where Israel has deployed hundreds of tanks and armored vehicles, as it prepares to invade Gaza.Â 
The military buildup seen in satellite images is some four miles north of the Erez Crossing, a primary entry point on Gaza's northern border.Â 
Tanks and other armored vehicles are seen in the pictures, which were taken at the end of last week by Planet Labs.Â 
Read more ....

Â 
Update #1: Israel Amassing Fleets Of Tanks On Northern Border Of Gaza - Ground Invasion Appears Imminent (Zero Hedge)
Â 
Update #2: Military build-up near Gaza as Israel prepares for ground offensive (First Post)

Â 
WNU Editor: It looks like northern Gaza is where the Israeli forces are going to focus their efforts when the ground offensive is launched.
articles.title: Satellite Images Show Hundreds Of Israeli Tanks Massing Near The Border Of Northern Gaza

The Hill: Americans urged to leave Lebanon âas soon as possibleâÂ 
The State Department on Thursday urged Americans to make plans to leave Lebanon âas soon as possible,â elevating an earlier security warning that advised Americans not to travel to the country.Â 
âThe U.S. Embassy is closely monitoring the security situation in Lebanon,â the Thursday advisory read.Â 
âThe Department of State urges U.S. citizens in Lebanon to make plans to depart as soon as possible while commercial options are still available.â

Â 
The test came hours after Russian lawmakers said they plan to revoke the ratification of a global nuclear test ban treatyÂ 
The U.S. conducted a high-explosive experiment at a nuclear test site in Nevada hours after Russia revoked a ban on atomic-weapons testing, which Moscow said would put it on par with the United States.Â 
Wednesday's test used chemicals and radioisotopes to "validate new predictive explosion models" that can help detect atomic blasts in other countries, Bloomberg reported, citing the Department of Energy.Â 
"These experiments advance our efforts to develop new technology in support of U.S. nuclear nonproliferation goals," Corey Hinderstein, Deputy Administrator for Defense Nâ¦
articles.title: U.S. Conducts Test To Detect Underground Nuclear Explosive Tests

articles.description:
Politico: Pentagon scours weapons stockpiles for Israel, even as Ukraine stresses industry

Â 
DOD has launched a new task force to rush weapons to the Middle East.Â 
The U.S. has launched a new effort to quickly find more precision weapons and artillery shells to rush to Israel as the Middle Eastern country conducts hundreds of strikes a day against Hamas targets in Gaza.Â 
A newly formed team inside the Pentagon has been tasked with scouring U.S. stockpiles, searching for ammunition to resupply Israel as it fires off munitions at a frantic pace, according to three people familiar with the effort.Â 
The move comes as the defense industry and the Pentagon scramble to send weapons to Ukraine and keep U.S. shelves stocked.

Â 
Read more ....Â 
Â Update: US eyes weapons stockpiles as concern grows about supporting both Ukraine and Israelâs wars (CNN)

Â 
WNU Editor: Here is an easy prediction. U.S. defense budget spending is going to go through the roof .... Defense spending boosts economy as U.S. mulls more aid for Ukraine and Israel (Market Watch).
articles.title: Pentagon Scours Its Weapons Stockpiles For Israel

articles.description:
Axios: Scoop: U.S. to send Israel artillery shells initially destined for UkraineÂ 
The Pentagon plans to send Israel tens of thousands of 155mm artillery shells that had been destined for Ukraine from U.S. emergency stocks several months ago, three Israeli officials with knowledge of the situation tell Axios.

Â 
Why it matters: The Israel Defense Forces and the Israeli Ministry of Defense told their U.S. counterparts they urgently need artillery shells to prepare for a ground invasion in Gaza â and a potential escalation of the war by Hezbollah along the Israel-Lebanon border, Israeli officials say.Â 
Â * U.S. officials have suggested that diverting the shells from Ukraine to Israel would have no immediate impact on Ukraine's ability to fight against Russian troops.Â 
* Less clear is whether U.S. military supplies to Ukraine could be stretched if the Israel-Hamas war becomes a broader regional conflict, but the Pentagon played down such concerns Thursday.

Â 
Read more ....Â 
Â WNU Editor: This is not a surprise. Israel is the priority for the U.S..Â 
US Rerouting Artillery Shells Meant For Ukraine To Israel

The White House has been forced to delete a photo of President Joe Biden meeting U.S. special forces in Israel - which showed their faces and could have revealed their identities.
It was already known that a small group of U.S. special forces are in Israel advising on how to potentially rescue scores of hostages, including Americans, held by terror group Hamas in Gaza.Â

â conflict zone (@kulio_zone) October 20, 2023
  
CNEWA: Orthodox Church Building in Gaza CollapsesÂ 
A multipurpose building of the Orthodox Church of St. Porphyrios in Gaza collapsed on 19 October after it was struck by a warhead. Hours after the attack, officials did not know the number of casualties, but dozens are feared dead beneath the rubble. The parish church, its school and adjacent church buildings had been sheltering up to 1,000 people, including the parents of a CNEWA staff member and on-the-ground partners, many of whom are parishioners.Â 
CNEWA learned of the building collapse from Joseph Hazboun, the regional director of CNEWAâs Jerusalem office.Â 
Mr. Hazboun said people have gathered at the bomb site to search for survivors, adding they are âin shock, trying hard to help as much as possible.â

âWe are all in tears.âÂ 
Read more ...

Â 
Update: Oldest Orthodox shrine in Gaza damaged by âIsraeli strikeââ church officials (RT)

Â 
WNU Editor: There are reports that the church and the area around it were sheltering 1,000 people. Mass casualties are feared. The Church of St. Porphyrios is a parish of the Orthodox Patriarchate of Jerusalem and is among the most historic in the region. Its foundations dating to the fifth century.
articles.title: Oldest Orthodox Shrine In Gaza Destriyed By âIsraeli Strikeâ. Mass Casualties Are Feared

Euronews: Kyiv a step closer to banning Ukrainian Orthodox Church Â 
Ukrainian lawmakers passed a bill on Thursday that would ban religious organisations and churches with alleged ties to Moscow.Â 
Ukraineâs lower house of parliament has passed a bill in the first of two required readings that would ban religious organisations and churches with alleged ties to Russia or in favour of its invasion of Ukraine.Â 
Kyiv accuses the Ukrainian Orthodox Church (UOC) specifically of collaborating with Russia after its invasion of the country in 2022.Â 
The bill was backed by 267 deputies and opposed by 15. It will become law if it passes a second reading and is signed by Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

Â 
Read more ....

Â 
Update: Ukraineâs parliament advances bill seen as targeting Orthodox church with historic ties to Moscow (AP)

WNU Editor: What can I say. This parliamentary vote was a sham. Ukraine's major opposition parties are banned and could not vote. And as for the vote. A fifth of the country has just been told that their church is now banned. So much for respecting human rights .... If Ukraine is truly committed to human rights, it must uphold its freedom of religion (William W. Burke-White, The Hill).
articles.title: Ukraine Government Moves To Ban The Ukraine Orthodox Church

SEOUL, Oct. 20 (Yonhap) -- North Korea on Friday condemned the arrival of a U.S. B-52 bomber in South Korea, threatening that U.S. strategic assets deployed on the Korean Peninsula will become the "first targets of destruction."Â 
Pyongyang's criticism came in response to the landing of the nuclear-capable bomber, a key U.S. strategic asset, at an air base in South Korea on Tuesday in its first known arrival in the South in a show of force against North Korea's nuclear and missile threats.Â 
"The U.S. would be well aware that the Korean Peninsula is in a state of war by law and its strategic assets deploying in the puppet region are the first targets of destruction," the North's official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) said in an English-language statement.

Â

Â

Iran called on its Arab-majority neighbors to impose an oil embargo on Israel as the Jewish state wages its war against Hamas.Â 
Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amirabdollahian on Wednesday called for the embargo and for nations within the Organization of Islamic Cooperation to expel all Israeli ambassadors.Â 
OPEC, the organization of largely Arab nations that overseas oil production in the Middle East, has no plans to impose such an embargo, Reuters reported Wednesday. The organization has no special or emergency meetings planned to discuss such a move.Â
